explanations.A: To compare Tom's numbers, write them on top of each other with the place value columns lined up. Covering up the "0." at the start of each number might help you.
explanations.B: Don't forget to consider the whole numbers as well as the decimal digits when comparing numbers.
explanations.C: I think you might be confused about the direction of the inequalities. The larger number goes next to the open side of the symbol: for example, 4 < 6 or 20 > 1. You can think of the inequality symbol as being greedy, because it looks like an open mouth, trying to eat the bigger number.
explanations.D: To compare decimals, we can write them on top of each other with the place value columns lined up. For Tom's numbers, we can cover up the zero and the point at the start because they are the same in both. The first digit after the decimal point is different in each number and 4 is greater than 1 so 0.42 must be greater than 0.15: we write this as 0.42 > 0.15. For Katie's numbers, we know that 2 is less than 4 so 2.51 must be less than 4.31: we write this as 2.51 < 4.31. So neither Tom nor Katie are correct because they both wrote the inequalities the wrong way.

explanations.A: If we write the numbers on top of each other with the place columns lined up, it is easier to compare them. Starting from the left in the ones column, 2.022 is the largest because it is the only number that has a 2 instead of a zero in the ones column. Next we check the tenths column after the decimal point: 0.202 and 0.220 both have two tenths but 0.022 has no tenths, so 0.022 must be the smallest number. Finally we check the hundredths column to compare 0.202 and 0.220: 0.202 has no hundredths but 0.220 has two hundredths so 0.202 is smaller. So in order from the smallest, we have 0.022, 0.202, 0.220 and 2.022.
explanations.B: Almost! The question asks us to start with the smallest number when we put them in order, not the largest.
